The Gap â€” A thorough, detailed exploration of the various pain points that the widely supported CSS 'gap' property solves. Lots of code examples and demos here to help you get a solid understanding ofÂ things.

Ahmad Shadeed

An Intro to CSS Anchor Positioning with Basic Examples â€” This is a solid overview of the CSS Anchoring API (already available in Chrome 125, others to follow), highlighting some of its shortcomings, the wins it introduces for creating complex layouts, andÂ more.

Brecht De Ruyte

Everything You Need to Know About Git â€” Join ThePrimeagen for this extensive video course and ensure you never run into an unsolvable Git problem again. You'll learn advanced git abilities like interactive rebasing, bisecting, worktrees, the reflog, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

CSS Length Units â€” A comprehensive guide covering nine types of lengths that CSS uses to size elements in terms of dimensions, space, time, and even sound. The sort of thing worthÂ bookmarking.

Geoff Graham

Geoff puts forward the case for starting with straightforward HTML & CSS, and even explains why going back to these key basics can enhance yourÂ career.

Myster Violets

Ross Moody

A-Frame 1.6: A Framework for Building WebVR Experiences â€” A web framework for building virtual reality experiences that work on Vive, Rift, Quest, as well as desktop and mobile platforms, including in the browser (as the demos hereÂ show).

A-Frame VR Team

lifeomic

items.title: Do you really need that framework?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹645 â€” May 29, 2024 | Read on the web

Old Dogs, New CSS Tricks? â€” We might be in the middle of a CSS renaissance, but with low uptake of many modern features, Max questions if 'feature fatigue' is setting in. He also considers what we can do to ensure uptake of these nice new features and how to fit them into our thoughtÂ processes.

Max BÃ¶ck

ğŸ“ŠÂ Hereâ€™s What We Learned From the First State of HTML Survey â€” A helpful recap of the key findings from the State of HTML survey results â€” a survey that over 20,000 of you filledÂ out.

Sacha Greif

Catch Page Speed Regressions Before They Happen! â€” "We actually don't need to log in much. We've set up performance budgets and deploy-based testing. We just wait to get alerts and then dive in to fix things". Track the metrics that matter, including Core Web Vitals. Stay fast. Find outÂ how.

SpeedCurve sponsor

Modern CSS Layouts: You Might Not Need a Framework For That â€” Various modern CSS features now offer simpler and more flexible approaches to styling and layout, without the added dependencies or abstractions that a framework may introduce. As such, Brecht is keen to encourage confidence in using CSS for those things that we tend to avoid doingÂ ourselves.

Brecht De Ruyte

A Comprehensive Guide to JS Performance Analysis with ChromeÂ DevTools â€” A surprisingly thorough walkthrough of the practicalities of using Chrome DevTools for digging into performanceÂ issues.

Jiayi Hu

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸï¸ An update from the Microsoft Edge team on recent speed improvements to theÂ browser.

  • ğŸ—³ï¸ The 'State of Frontend 2024' survey is currently seekingÂ responses.

  • ğŸ“– Manuel Matuzovic has a new book out next month on web accessibility (Web Accessibility Cookbook, published by O'Reilly). Pre-orders are openÂ now.

  • ğŸ” The W3C has unveiled 174 'new outcomes' for WCAGÂ 3.0.

  • ğŸ”— A handy DevTools snippet for finding brokenÂ links.

  • ğŸ‚ The WordPress project is now 21 yearsÂ young.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â â€œAct on Pressâ€ - John Carmack's Hot Take on UI â€” A video response to a recent, lengthy tweet from John Carmack (of Quake and Armadillo Aerospace fame) on user interface interaction responsiveness. Theo says: â€œonMouseDown might be my goto in theÂ futureâ€. Lots of debate on the rightÂ approach.

Theo Browne

Masonry and Reading Order â€” Thereâ€™s been plenty of debate lately around so-called masonry layouts, and Rachel (of the Chrome team) wants to address some additional questions around it, specifically on the content reordering issue that masonryÂ presents.

Rachel Andrew

5 Easy Tips to Improve Your Personal Website Performance â€” Salma Alam-Naylor shares easy ways to give your personal website (and all other websites, in fact) a performanceÂ boost.

Sentry sponsor

City in a Bottle: Raycasting in 256 Bytes of HTML and CSS â€” Frank has a reputation for putting together stunning visual demos with the tiniest amounts of code. This is no exception. He goes into a lot of detail about how it works here. Who needsÂ megabytes?

Frank Force

/Â Slash Pages: A Guide to Common Base-Level Web Site Pages â€” Some suggestions for what pages (such as /about, /contact, /sitemap, etc.) you may want to consider adding to yourÂ site.

Robb Knight

Stop Resizing Your Browser: Improve Testing for Responsiveness â€” â€œWhen you resize your browser, youâ€™re not testing for responsiveness. Youâ€™re testing the side effect of how a layout looks when you resize aÂ browser.â€

jen chan

Modern WordPress - Yikes? â€” Sharing some frustrations on the current state of WordPress and the â€˜code-within-codeâ€™ inception found within the codebase. â€œI loathe what WordPress development hasÂ becomeâ€.

David Bushell

Best Practices for Naming Design Tokens, Components, Variables, and More
Cosima Mielke

Creating an Accessible Toggle Switch in Tailwind CSS
Kyndrea Martinez

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Fontsource: 1700+ Open Source Fonts in npm Packages â€” On the surface, itâ€™s a handy way to browse and filter over a thousand different Web fonts (from Google Fonts as well as other sources), but go a step further and you can integrate fonts into your apps in a version-locked manner by way of npm (or just grab a ZIP, if youÂ prefer).

Fontsource

Signature Pad 5.0: Smooth Signature Drawing for the Web â€” If you need people to give you their signature or similar scrawls on the Web, you can use this to let them scribble away easily. GitHubÂ repo.

Szymon Nowak

Drawing the Auth Owl at Userfront | Transformational Auth &Â Identity â€” Read the story behind Userfront. Including the vision behind the company and what auth should (and shouldn't)Â have.

Userfront sponsor

selectlist-polyfill: Polyfill for the Proposed <selectlist>Â Element â€” Based on a proposal from Open UI, seen here, this polyfill (which depends on the Popover API) aims to overcome the styling and interoperability problems inherent in using the <select> element.

Wesley Luyten

jessquery: A Lightweight jQuery Alternative for the Modern Web â€” Aims to provide a similar experience to using jQuery by offering a wrapper around the DOM API for easier DOM manipulation at a fraction of the size. Itâ€™s well-documented and works withÂ TypeScript.

Jesse Pence

Bau.js: A Small, Reactive Library and Components for Building User Interfaces â€” You can check out the 50+ styleable components here, and the library itself boasts no JSX, no templating, no virtual DOM, a CSS-in-JS solution, integration with Astro, among otherÂ features.

GruCloud

OKLCH Color Variations â€” A neat Figma plugin for creating accessible color palettes using the OKLCH colorÂ space.

Abhishek Y

CodeMender: A Platform to Help Frontend Devs Master the Art ofÂ Debugging â€” Includes a small collection of free and premium real-world JavaScript project bugs of varying difficulty levels, to help you sharpen your debuggingÂ skills.

CodeMender

ğŸ„ ...and finally

Super CSS Mario â€” A slightly wobbly but CSS-only keyboard game in which Mario has to collect some coins whilst avoiding Goombas â€“ the usual story. Itâ€™s a Chromium-only experiment, so wonâ€™t work in Firefox orÂ Safari. (If you're on a non-Chromium browser, here's another Mario flavored visualization to playÂ with.)

Temani Afif Codepen

Last week, Google's annual developer conference took place, and now we've got a handful of relevant videos to share with you from the show. There's a full playlist here if you'd rather pick your own to watch.

What's New in the Web â€” Covers new, interoperable features available across browsers, and how Baseline helps highlightÂ these.

The Latest in Web UI â€” Una highlights the latest CSS developments, UI components, and interactions on the web platform, along with what the Chrome team are doing to push thingsÂ forward.

There's plenty of CodePen exercises too to help best understand the techniques you'llÂ need.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Rethinking Text Resizing on the Web â€” An in-depth look at how Airbnb approached improving web accessibility at scale, particularly around text size, going beyond browser zoom settings, the challenge such changes could introduce, and the subsequentÂ benefits.

Steven Bassett (Airbnb)

What UI Density Means and How to Design for It â€” A thoughtful look at how user interface density has changed over the past twenty or so years, defining what such a term means today, along with some thoughts on which approach we should beÂ taking.

Matthew StrÃ¶m

Lea Verou

Weâ€™ve Got Container Queries Now, But Are We Actually UsingÂ Them? â€” Posits that container query adoption isnâ€™t particularly high, and then shares some reasons as to why that may be the case (beyond it just being new, and any potential browser supportÂ concerns).

Chris Coyier

contrast-color() is a Good Thing, But Also Solving the Problem at the Wrong Layer â€” On the other hand.. some considered thoughts on the new CSS contrast-color() function and how it may placing the effort in the â€˜wrongâ€™Â place.

Eric Bailey

Open-Source JavaScript Form Builder to Create Dynamic Forms Right in Your App â€” With SurveyJS library suite, you can build JSON-driven forms in a fully-integrated no-code form builder and store responses in any backend, inc. PHP, ASP.NET Core, andÂ Node.js.

SurveyJS sponsor

Navigating the Variety of Web Accessibility Evaluation Tools â€” A handy, in-depth guide on web accessibility evaluation tools, their features, and effectiveÂ usage.

Caitlin de Rooij

Weighing In on CSS Masonry â€” â€œShould masonry be its own display method outside grid? Absolutely.â€

Keith J. Grant

<style>: Inline Optimizations for the Bold â€” Some brief thoughts on the potential performance bump of inlineÂ CSS.

Morgan Murrah

Hidden vs. Disabled In UX â€” Considerations for hiding versus disabling, along with possible alternatives to improve yourÂ UX.

Vitaly Friedman

We Need to Talk More About Conformance, If We Want to Stop Fantasy HTML
Jens Oliver Meiert

CSS3? Pfff. Get Ready for CSS6!
Jared White

CSS Pattern: Fancy Backgrounds with CSS Gradients â€” A collection of nice background patterns, now 144 strong, made with justÂ CSS. We first shared this last year, but it's had lots of updates since.

Temani Afif

Instant, Detailed Online Store Performance Analysis for Devs â€” Analyze site performance and get clear next steps for improvement with Elastic Pathâ€™s free StorefrontÂ Graderâ„¢.

Elastic Path sponsor

Vue Fluid DnD: An Animated Drag-and-Drop Library for Vue â€” Designed for lists of items and you can view a variety of examples here, including one where the items are draggable using handles. GitHubÂ repo.

Carlos Jorge Rodriguez

Gradientor: A Minimalist, Beautiful Radial Background Generator â€” Mostly for inspiration, the tool lets you click, move the mouse, and scroll to change the color, position, and size of the gradient and you can choose from three types of colors (vibrant, pastel, orÂ monochromatic).

rodolfo fanti
